awd_titl_txt: Online Spatiotemporal Filtering and Bayesian Topology for Tracking in Dynamically Designed Sensor Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on the problem of predicting threats' trajectories in realtime designed sensor networks. Sensor networks facilitate the collection of information in different environments. The quality of this information relies on the design of the network, which in turn is associated with the network's coverage and online predictability. Indeed, sensor networks are prone to threats, which are quite spatiotemporally unpredictable, and if they are not detected and monitored promptly, they may have a devastating socioeconomic impact.

This project engages homological techniques with data assimilation to (i) establish a novel method for online designing a sensor network whose coverage is queried in real time, and (ii) predict trajectories of spatiotemporally dynamic objects moving in the network using an innovative sequential empirical Bayes scheme. The coverage of the network is verified within a new probabilistic setting in the space of persistence diagrams by computing their distribution. Assimilating the collected data and estimating the parameters associated with spatiotemporal uncertainty in the network, the real-time design is derived as a function of the underlying posterior filtering distribution, related to the threats' underlying motion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sensor networks facilitate the collection of information in different environments. The quality of this information may rely on the network itself, which in turn is associated with the network's coverage and the ability to predict future information based on currently collected data. In this project, the network’s coverage is queried by computing its topological summaries, called persistent diagrams. However, due to the underlying uncertainty, we established a Bayesian framework for quantifying the uncertainty in the network, and estimated the distribution of the persistence diagrams which in turn provided the network's void space (coverage). Due to the computational complexity of the persistence diagrams distributions, we established a closed form solution for the posterior using a Gaussian mixture prior, and we showed that it was a conjugate family of priors when the likelihood was a Gaussian distribution. To that end, the posterior is tractable and fully computable using a pertinent Gaussian mixture (Maroulas et al., 2020).   Moreover, we considered the case of a uniform prior relying on point process theory, and this yielded a posterior, which was nonparametrically estimated by a pertinent kernel density based on random set theory (Maroulas et al., 2019). Using to our advantage this Bayesian scheme for estimating a network’s coverage via persistent homology, we engaged this result with the ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF) in order to estimate trajectories of objects which were moving within a sensing network field. As a showcase scenario, we examined the robustness and accuracy of our method using bioimaging data. Precisely, we focused on organelles, which were moving across networks of filaments whose length may dynamically vary. The organelles' motion is in general related to cellular growth, and the biologists’ goal is to accurately and automatically monitor these intracellular movements. Our Bayesian topological method quantified the shape uncertainty of these networks, and in synergy with the EnKF, the velocity of the organelles was predicted and updated, and their trajectories were predicted. The "converging" combination of  EnKF with the posterior distribution of persistence diagrams was fully Bayesian, and our method exhibited an accurately robust behavior as revealed by these data (Yin et al., 2019).

Our approach in detecting shape patterns in networks was expanded to detecting features in chemical compounds related to gas separation (Townsend et  al.,  2020). Furthermore, relying on our Bayesian method for computing distributions of persistence diagrams, we constructed a Bayesian supervised learning method for classifying data based on their topological signatures. Indeed, our classification scheme was tested in different scientific and engineering applications in materials science by classifying the crystal structure of high entropy alloys, (Spannaus et al. 2021), to neuroscience by detecting different brain states based on electroencephalogram (EEG) recordings, (Nasrin et al. 2019). Understanding neuroactivity using topological data analysis led us to the path that topological data analysis was a critical way forward in understanding deep learning and its underlying connectivity considerations (Love et al., 2021),  (Oballe et al. 2021). We also established a data assimilation scheme for understanding rare events (using large deviations) in a network where objects follow discontinuous trajectories and estimated the associated intensity of the driving jump process, the reason for the discontinuities (Maroulas et al. 2019). During the duration of the project three PhD students were partially supported and trained at the interplay between Bayesian statistics, machine learning, and topological data analysis, and a related graduate course is under development and ready to launch.
